articles.headline: A Bank Too Big to Jail
articles.snippet: A House committee’s report details how regulators and prosecutors turned a potential criminal prosecution of HSBC into a watered-down settlement.
articles.abstract: A House committee’s report details how regulators and prosecutors turned a potential criminal prosecution of HSBC into a watered-down settlement.
articles.lead_paragraph: Have you ever wondered why the crippling 2008 financial crisis generated almost no criminal prosecutions of large banks and their top executives?
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson

articles.headline: Behind Volkswagen Settlement, Speed and Compromise
articles.snippet: It was one of the fastest civil settlements in the history of corporate malfeasance, but fraught with pitfalls, including clashing egos and cultures.
articles.abstract: It was one of the fastest civil settlements in the history of corporate malfeasance, but fraught with pitfalls, including clashing egos and cultures.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was one of the fastest civil settlements in the history of corporate malfeasance, coming together in six months instead of the years usually required for such complex negotiations. But the path to Volkswagen’s $15 billion deal last month with American officials and car owners over the company’s diesel deception was fraught with pitfalls, including clashing egos and cultures, arguments over mathematical formulas and frayed nerves from late nights and lost weekends.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: Turkish President Returns to Istanbul in Sign Military Coup Is Faltering
articles.snippet: Vowing that faction leaders will “pay a heavy price,” President Recep Tayyip Erdogan made a dramatic appearance after his supporters flooded the streets of Turkey’s largest city.
articles.abstract: Vowing that faction leaders will “pay a heavy price,” President Recep Tayyip Erdogan made a dramatic appearance after his supporters flooded the streets of Turkey’s largest city.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A military coup attempt plunged Turkey into a long night of violence and intrigue on Friday, threatening its embattled president, leaving nearly 200 dead and injecting new instability into a crucial NATO member and American ally in the chaotic Middle East.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Ceylan Yeginsu

articles.headline: Makers of Humira and Enbrel Using New Drug Patents to Delay Generic Versions
articles.snippet: Six years after the Affordable Care Act cleared the way for biosimilars, as the generic versions of biotechnology drugs are called, progress has been slow.
articles.abstract: Six years after the Affordable Care Act cleared the way for biosimilars, as the generic versions of biotechnology drugs are called, progress has been slow.
articles.lead_paragraph: The best-selling drugs Humira and Enbrel have a lot in common. They both use biotechnology to treat rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis and other autoimmune diseases. And they come with giant price tags approaching $50,000 a year.
articles.byline: By Andrew Pollack

articles.headline: In Truck Attack in Nice, Mainstay of Commerce Reinvented as Tool of Death
articles.snippet: The rampage opened a frightening new landscape of terrorism, using a weapon that is ubiquitous on roads in the United States and was encouraged by Al Qaeda years ago.
articles.abstract: The rampage opened a frightening new landscape of terrorism, using a weapon that is ubiquitous on roads in the United States and was encouraged by Al Qaeda years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than five years ago, Al Qaeda called on its followers to use cars as tools of terror. Soon after, the terrorist group that had brought down the twin towers scrapped the idea, feeling that the tactic was too indiscriminate, too likely to kill Muslims.
articles.byline: By Rukmini Callimachi

articles.headline: Trump Wants War Declared on ISIS and ‘Extreme Vetting’ of Immigrants
articles.snippet: The statements strike the same chords of hostility and suspicion toward Muslims and immigrants that are at the heart of Mr. Trump’s appeal to many voters.
articles.abstract: The statements strike the same chords of hostility and suspicion toward Muslims and immigrants that are at the heart of Mr. Trump’s appeal to many voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Within four hours of the attack on the French Riviera, Donald J. Trump pledged to seek a rare declaration of war from Congress against Islamic terrorists and called for “extreme vetting” of immigrants and a complete ban on those from “terrorist nations.”
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: A Surly Misfit With No Terror Links Turned a Truck Into a Tank
articles.snippet: The suspect in the rampage that killed 84 people in Nice had run-ins with the law but no record of radicalization, and left no declaration of a motive.
articles.abstract: The suspect in the rampage that killed 84 people in Nice had run-ins with the law but no record of radicalization, and left no declaration of a motive.
articles.lead_paragraph: NICE, France — He lived on the 12th floor of a high rise in a heavily immigrant housing project and was known to his neighbors only as a moody and aggressive oddball. He never went to the local mosque, often grunted in response to greetings of “bonjour” and sometimes beat his wife — until she threw him out.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins

articles.headline: Donald Trump’s Deals Rely on Being Creative With the Truth
articles.snippet: Over the span of his career, project after project has produced allegations of bad faith, broken promises, blatant lies or outright fraud.
articles.abstract: Over the span of his career, project after project has produced allegations of bad faith, broken promises, blatant lies or outright fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: There was the time Donald J. Trump told Larry King that he had been paid more than $1 million to give a speech about his business acumen when in fact he was paid $400,000. Or the time he sought a bank loan claiming a net worth of $3.5 billion in 2004, four times as much as what the bank found when it checked his math. Or the time he boasted that membership to Trump National Golf Club in Westchester County, N.Y., cost $300,000 when the actual initiation fee was $200,000. Or the time he bragged on CNBC about his new Trump International Hotel and Tower in Las Vegas, claiming, “We have 1,282 units, and they sold out in less than a week.” As Mr. Trump knew, more than 300 units had not been sold.
articles.byline: By David Barstow

articles.headline: When Yahoo Ruled the Valley: Stories of the Original ‘Surfers’
articles.snippet: As Yahoo puts itself on the auction block, some of its first employees revisit their youth spent building a company that defined the early web.
articles.abstract: As Yahoo puts itself on the auction block, some of its first employees revisit their youth spent building a company that defined the early web.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUNNYVALE, Calif. — Back in the mid-1990s, before Google even existed, the world’s best guides to the internet sat in Silicon Valley cubicles, visiting websites and carefully categorizing them by hand.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel

articles.headline: As Turkey Coup Unfolded, ‘the Whole Night Felt Like Doomsday’
articles.snippet: Thousands of soldiers and officers were purged from the military as the government of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan sought to assert control.
articles.abstract: Thousands of soldiers and officers were purged from the military as the government of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan sought to assert control.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Thousands of soldiers and officers purged from the military. A helicopter shot down over the capital. Hundreds of people lying dead on city streets.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Ceylan Yeginsu

articles.headline: Philando Castile Was Pulled Over 49 Times in 13 Years, Often for Minor Infractions
articles.snippet: Mr. Castile’s death from a police shooting during a traffic stop is seen by many as an illustration of the disproportionate risks black motorists face.
articles.abstract: Mr. Castile’s death from a police shooting during a traffic stop is seen by many as an illustration of the disproportionate risks black motorists face.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — Turning into a parking lot without signaling. Failing to repair a broken seatbelt. Driving at night with an unlit license plate. Driving with tinted windows.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Mitch Smith

articles.headline: Donald Trump the Political Showman, Born on ‘The Apprentice’
articles.snippet: On the reality show that Donald Trump began hosting in 2004, he displayed the showmanship and other traits that have come to define his 2016 presidential campaign.
articles.abstract: On the reality show that Donald Trump began hosting in 2004, he displayed the showmanship and other traits that have come to define his 2016 presidential campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: He hounded network executives at all hours, demanding Nielsen reports and asking: “How’d we do? How’d we do?”
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: How Mike Pence Became a Conservative Hero: Unwavering Opposition to Abortion
articles.snippet: Mr. Pence’s reputation as a longstanding, implacable and dogged opponent of abortion has made him a hero to the country’s cultural conservatives.
articles.abstract: Mr. Pence’s reputation as a longstanding, implacable and dogged opponent of abortion has made him a hero to the country’s cultural conservatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: One by one, Republican women of the Indiana state legislature rose to describe, in anguished terms, why they could not support an anti-abortion measure hurtling toward passage.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: Terror Through the Eyes of Innocents: The Children in Nice
articles.snippet: The attack during the Bastille Day fireworks show, an annual attraction for families, underscored the act’s brutality, with at least 10 children killed and leaving many with memories of trauma.
articles.abstract: The attack during the Bastille Day fireworks show, an annual attraction for families, underscored the act’s brutality, with at least 10 children killed and leaving many with memories of trauma.
articles.lead_paragraph: NICE, France — It was the first and last fireworks show in this seaside city that 4½-year-old Yanis Coviaux ever saw. He died in the carnage Thursday night. So did Brodie Copeland, 11, who was visiting from the United States.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin and Lilia Blaise

articles.headline: Baton Rouge Shooting Jolts a Nation on Edge
articles.snippet: Three officers were killed and three wounded in the attack, which left many wondering whether anger at the police had prompted yet another act of retaliation.
articles.abstract: Three officers were killed and three wounded in the attack, which left many wondering whether anger at the police had prompted yet another act of retaliation.
articles.lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — A gunman fatally shot three law enforcement officers and wounded three others here on Sunday before being killed in a shootout with the police. The attack’s motive was unclear as of Sunday evening, leaving an anxious nation to wonder whether the anger over recent police shootings had prompted another act of retaliation against officers.
articles.byline: By Julie Bloom, Richard Fausset and Mike McPhate

articles.headline: Erdogan Triumphs After Coup Attempt, but Turkey’s Fate Is Unclear
articles.snippet: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s victory over the uprising may have bolstered his popularity among Islamists, but wider support was not yet certain.
articles.abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s victory over the uprising may have bolstered his popularity among Islamists, but wider support was not yet certain.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Standing atop a bus outside his mansion in Istanbul on Saturday night, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, victorious after putting down a coup attempt by renegade factions of the military, told his followers, “We only bow to God.”
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Ceylan Yeginsu

articles.headline: Artificial Intelligence Swarms Silicon Valley on Wings and Wheels
articles.snippet: The valley has found its next shiny new thing in A.I., and financiers and entrepreneurs are digging in with remarkable exuberance.
articles.abstract: The valley has found its next shiny new thing in A.I., and financiers and entrepreneurs are digging in with remarkable exuberance.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUNNYVALE, Calif. — For more than a decade, Silicon Valley’s technology investors and entrepreneurs obsessed over social media and mobile apps that helped people do things like find new friends, fetch a ride home or crowdsource a review of a product or a movie.
articles.byline: By John Markoff

articles.headline: In the Age of ISIS, Who’s a Terrorist, and Who’s Simply Deranged?
articles.snippet: Instances of wanton violence have been swiftly judged to be the work of terrorists, even when there is little evidence of direct ties to terrorist groups.
articles.abstract: Instances of wanton violence have been swiftly judged to be the work of terrorists, even when there is little evidence of direct ties to terrorist groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In December 2014, a middle-aged man driving a car in Dijon, France, mowed down more than a dozen pedestrians within 30 minutes, occasionally shouting Islamic slogans from his window.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Bridgewater, World’s Biggest Hedge Fund, Is Said to Be Slowing Hiring
articles.snippet: The firm, which usually hires hundreds of people yearly, has canceled interviews and cut short negotiations, said people briefed on the matter.
articles.abstract: The firm, which usually hires hundreds of people yearly, has canceled interviews and cut short negotiations, said people briefed on the matter.
articles.lead_paragraph: After years of rapid internal growth, the world’s biggest hedge fund appears to be slowing down.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: With Pokémon Go, Nintendo Seeks to Salvage Lost Opportunity
articles.snippet: Nearly two decades ago, the video game company released a forerunner to today’s game that foreshadowed much of mobile gaming. Then it lost its lead.
articles.abstract: Nearly two decades ago, the video game company released a forerunner to today’s game that foreshadowed much of mobile gaming. Then it lost its lead.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A video game featuring combative little critters called Pokémon hits mobile devices, and millions of fans are hooked. Players around the world search for rare and valuable Pokémon and connect with each other to do battle.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Jonathan Soble

articles.headline: TV News: Truth Squad or Trump Infomercial?
articles.snippet: With convention plans calling for spectacle, truth will not come to the fore without hard work by the media and, potentially, a fight.
articles.abstract: With convention plans calling for spectacle, truth will not come to the fore without hard work by the media and, potentially, a fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — In the months since he began pursuing the presidency, Donald J. Trump has exhibited a command over the national news media that is without parallel in modern times.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Murdoch Brothers’ Challenge: What Happens Next at Fox News?
articles.snippet: Since taking the reins of 21st Century Fox, James and Lachlan Murdoch have made changes big and small, but have largely left Fox News alone. Now they have little choice but to step in.
articles.abstract: Since taking the reins of 21st Century Fox, James and Lachlan Murdoch have made changes big and small, but have largely left Fox News alone. Now they have little choice but to step in.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — They have shaken up 21st Century Fox’s profile in Washington, replacing their father’s Republican lobbying chief with a Democratic one. They have jettisoned film executives, overhauled foreign TV operations and dug into the evolution of cable channels like National Geographic.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Emily Steel

articles.headline: On Eve of G.O.P. Convention, Law and Order Takes the Floor
articles.snippet: After three police officers were fatally shot in Louisiana, Donald J. Trump is likely to amplify his “law-and-order” campaign theme.
articles.abstract: After three police officers were fatally shot in Louisiana, Donald J. Trump is likely to amplify his “law-and-order” campaign theme.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The attack on police officers in Baton Rouge, La., cast a grim mood over the opening of the Republican National Convention here, as Donald J. Trump responded to the killings with a stark warning that the country was falling apart.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Baton Rouge Attack Deepens Anguish for Police: ‘We’ve Seen Nothing Like This’
articles.snippet: Law enforcement officials said it had been generations since the nation endured two separate episodes in which so many police officers were killed.
articles.abstract: Law enforcement officials said it had been generations since the nation endured two separate episodes in which so many police officers were killed.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Officer down!” an officer screamed frantically into his police radio Sunday morning in Baton Rouge, La. “Shots fired! Officer down!”
articles.byline: By Timothy Williams and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: SoftBank’s $32 Billion Deal for Chip Designer ARM Is Britain’s Biggest Since Brexit
articles.snippet: The deal gives the Japanese company access to chip designs for phones and other small devices.
articles.abstract: The deal gives the Japanese company access to chip designs for phones and other small devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Masayoshi Son, the billionaire Japanese technology investor, solidified his control over his SoftBank internet conglomerate last month, he told shareholders he still wanted to “work on a few more crazy ideas.”
articles.byline: By Leslie Picker, Mark Scott and Jonathan Soble

articles.headline: For Want of a Coffeepot, Your Flight Is Delayed
articles.snippet: Of the things that can delay takeoff, an out-of-order coffee maker might seem mundane. But fixing the problem is not as simple as it might seem.
articles.abstract: Of the things that can delay takeoff, an out-of-order coffee maker might seem mundane. But fixing the problem is not as simple as it might seem.
articles.lead_paragraph: The captain is at the controls, the tray tables are stowed, and nobody is smoking in the lavatories. We’ll be taking off shortly.
articles.byline: By Annalyn Kurtz

articles.headline: Vast Purge in Turkey as Thousands Are Detained in Post-Coup Backlash
articles.snippet: The Interior Ministry fired nearly 9,000 police officers on Monday, officials said, coming after the arrests of 6,000 military personnel and suspensions of nearly 3,000 judges.
articles.abstract: The Interior Ministry fired nearly 9,000 police officers on Monday, officials said, coming after the arrests of 6,000 military personnel and suspensions of nearly 3,000 judges.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The Turkish government’s crackdown after a military coup attempt widened into a sweeping purge on Monday, cutting a swath through the security services and reaching deeply into the government bureaucracy and the political and business classes.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango, Ceylan Yeginsu and Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: Online Trail Illuminates Baton Rouge Gunman’s Path to Violence
articles.snippet: The gunman, a Marine veteran, appears to have been obsessed with self-improvement, even as he spiraled toward an ambush that killed three officers.
articles.abstract: The gunman, a Marine veteran, appears to have been obsessed with self-improvement, even as he spiraled toward an ambush that killed three officers.
articles.lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — He joined the Marines, served in Iraq and earned a Good Conduct Medal. He was an entrepreneur, a self-published author, a nutrition and fitness counselor, a proponent of the American gospel of self-improvement. He considered himself a lifestyle coach, even though he had failed in marriage, neglected to pay his taxes and was, at one point, living on $500 per month. He had also embarked on a spiritual quest to find his roots as a black man, traveling around Africa for two years.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset, Frances Robles and John Eligon
